content: Is this what you mean? My old hard drive is Local Disk (E:)
creator: sales388

content:
Yes, click the Users folder. Under that should be a folder that may include your name or part of your name. Click that and a folder named Appdata should appear in the list. Click that and a folder named Roaming should appear. And there will then appear a folder named Thunderbird. - now, if thunderbird is installed already, you can do a full recovery that will overlay whatever is already there. If that is the desire, just copy the thunderbird folder from drive E to 

  c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming    That will OVERWRITE the existing thunderbird folder

- now, just restart thunderbird

If you have already started using Thunderbird and have messages saved, then the process of salvaging the old PC gets messier. I'll wait for your response.
creator: davidsk

content: Update: from a quick review of your screenshot, it appears your Thunderbird account is already active. In that case, recovering the old messages will need some details. So, once you locate the thunderbird folder, do this: - open the file, profile.ini. It will have the name of the profile that was being used. Look next in the subdirectory named profiles for the folder with that name. That was the active profile. Click it. Now, your POP and/or local folders will be in the Mail folder. Folders will have names such as inbox, inbox.msf, etc. Once you find the ones you want, I suggest this: - make new local folders in the Local Folders area with unique names for each of the folders to keep. - install the importexport addon if not already done - highlight one of the new folders, rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox - select one of the identified folders on drive e and import it. - repeat these steps for each of the desired folders.
creator: davidsk

content:
I don;t think Thunderbird has any ability to limit your ability to send mail. Your antivirus or mail provider however are very different issues.

I did a google search in the message you posted mfrm-502 and I would have to say all of the responses I got were from exchange servers refusing to send mail for what they termed abuse. This discussion includes links on the action to take when trying to have you mail account removed from the abuse list, but essentially you need to contact your mail server admin. https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/outlook_com/forum/all/i-receive-this-message-when-i-press-sendreceive-in/14c1551d-7359-4e7a-989d-6e569ea7f5c7
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Some possibilities: - if you aren't using secure settings, your server may not be recognizing you. - if your sending email id doesn't match the SMTP server email id, that would also cause refusal.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hello there


These icons may eventually disappear depending on what kind of operating system you have and also what kind of computer you use.

Do you have any duplicates on your computer that you should have already deleted after this update to the latest release of Thunderbird software?

try going to your profile folder on the pc itself , where these add ons and extensions are stored in your previous folder.

check whether there is a similar add-on or extension available. Has your extension or add-on been assigned an unknown name in profile storage or does it already contain one? To be sure, open the add-ons you found in an editor where you can see the entire add-on or a description of it.

Try to delete them of try to delete them all. You can also delete these addon files in one time.

Does this extensions and addons folder still have the same name or has it been changed to a number-like code?

Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird
